title: Multi element conditionals trap the developer with key warnings
body:
The standard way to do `if` for something in the middle of a block of jsx is with a ternary or boolean expression. (ie: `{this.props.condition && foo}`) If you need to do a conditional for multiple elements the natural method I expect would be: ``` jsx {this.props.condition && [

Foo

,

Bar

]} ``` However doing so generates warnings like: > "Warning: Each child in an array or iterator should have a unique "key" prop. Check the React.render call using `

`. See https://fb.me/react-warning-keys for more information." This array isn't a list of things that'll be reordered or anything, it's just a set of elements that are all conditional together. None of the alternatives to avoid the warning are very good. A) Add key="" to each of the element. For a few elements, which might even be inline elements like a `` next to two strings, being forced to add a key="" is really overboard. B) Do the condition for each element separately: ``` jsx {condition &&

Foo

} {condition &&

Bar

} ``` ...I don't think I need to explain why repeating the same code over and over is a bad thing. C) Wrap the elements in one element: ``` jsx {this.props.condition &&

Foo

,

Bar

} ``` Adding extra elements into code should not be required when those elements only exist to satisfy React quirks and are not actually needed inside the DOM.
